ipPlan.title: IPv6 Address Plan
ipPlan.intro: Our IPv6 network uses a Provider Independent address space (2001:db8::/32), fully statically assigned. Each VLAN has its own Global Unicast prefix, and transport networks between routers use Unique Local IPv6 addresses (fd00::/8).

conclusion.title: Conclusion & Reflection
conclusion.intro: This project gave us the opportunity to apply IPv6 networking concepts in a practical, collaborative setup. Here‚Äôs what stood out.
whatWentWell: Team coordination through Trello and clearly assigned roles
Scrum helped us track progress and adapt during configuration
All routers communicated successfully using static routes
SSH access was secured and tested for each router
challenges: Early VLAN tagging inconsistencies between switches and routers
SSH login didn‚Äôt work initially due to missing VTY configuration
Some IP assignments were misaligned before route validation
Testing with Packet Tracer CLI sometimes gave unexpected results
learnings: Hands-on experience with IPv6 prefix planning and VLAN structuring
Troubleshooting network errors using real commands
Working together under pressure during test and validation phase
Understanding why planning and naming conventions are so important

api.title: API Documentation & Design Overview
api.intro: To support integration, automation, and transparency in our project, we designed a RESTful API that delivers key project data through structured endpoints. Here's how it was planned and implemented.

answers.question: What is your motivation for implementing those APIs?
answers.answer: To provide machine-readable access to project structure and configuration data and enable frontends and scripts to interact with it efficiently.

answers.question: What is the purpose of this API?
answers.answer: To expose our IPv6 network design, address plan, configuration snippets, and team structure in JSON format.

answers.question: Who is the user?
answers.answer: Project team members, instructors, and any tool or app needing programmatic access to our data.

answers.question: What user pains are we solving or gains are we creating?
answers.answer: Reduces manual updates, enables visualization tools, supports modular, scalable documentation.

answers.question: What concrete outcomes do we want to achieve with these APIs?
answers.answer: Enable a GUI to render all core project data and support automated testing and validation flows.

answers.question: How do we plan to execute the API program?
answers.answer: Using Express.js to deliver static and dynamic endpoints during development, deploy-ready via Node.js.

answers.question: What is the architectural style and why?
answers.answer: REST ‚Äì it's stateless, simple to consume, and integrates well with both frontend and external tools.
